reasoning:
The critique targets the paper’s Section 2.4 move: using a multiplicative ‘product of factors’ model to explain why mostly-great futures are rare. That is a meaningful support for the paper’s intuitive case for fragility, but it is not the sole or necessary support for the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion (which also leans heavily on the many moral-catastrophe examples in 2.1–2.3 and the more systematic ‘fussy vs easygoing value functions’ analysis in Section 3). Hence moderate centrality.

On strength: it fairly presses that the multiplicative functional form is doing much of the work in producing extreme skew/fragility and that alternative aggregators (e.g., additive/averaging, or weaker complementarity) could yield very different distributions from similar “factor scores.” This does weaken any inference from the toy model to ‘eutopia is generally fragile.’ However, it doesn’t fully refute the intended role of 2.4, which is presented as a suggestive model/analogy rather than a demonstrated moral law; the paper also gives some (limited) motivation via analogies to wealth/wellbeing and complementarity. So the refutation is partial.

Correctness is fairly high: it is true that multiplication encodes strong complementarity and can make single low dimensions disproportionately damaging. But it overstates slightly by implying the paper treats multiplication as a ‘discovery’ rather than an illustrative model, and by suggesting it ‘presupposes zeroing out’ (the toy model uses factors in (0,1), so it doesn’t literally allow one factor to set value to zero, though it can make it arbitrarily small). The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: The multiplicative model assumes fragility rather than discovering it
